Award.AwardTitle: Calcification by amorphous pathways: Establishing effects of acidification and interplays with Mg and biomolecule chemistry
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed work will focus on understanding calcification by marine organisms and will challenge the long-standing view that precipitation occurs via classical crystallization processes. The interpretation of many past studies is based on this notion. It now appears that most carbonate-producing organisms form skeletons by non-classical growth processes which involve an amorphous phase that transforms to a composite of mesocrystals over time. If this is true then the current approaches to inferring environmental effects, and interpreting paleo records, from analysis of calcite skeletons, either recently formed or preserved in marine sediments, will need to be revised as skeleton formation by non-classical processes relies on a different set of chemical and environmental conditions. The proposed research will build on recent findings which suggest that acidification, magnesium concentration, biomolecule chemistry and other factors all influence this pathway to mineralization. The project will investigate a number of hypotheses based on this new paradigm using laboratory studies and innovative analytical approaches. Kinetic and thermodynamic measurements and modeling will be coupled with chemical and structural investigations to establish a complete physical picture of the biomineralization pathway.

The scientific broader impacts of the research go beyond the field of Chemical Oceanography and will have substantial impact if the proposed hypotheses are confirmed. The project has significant educational aspects, with the inclusion of both graduates and undergraduates in the research, and K-12 education development through the NSF-funded Earth to Life series.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Significant advances were made in our understanding of skeleton calcification and how biomineralization processes influence the composition, and potentially the physical properties, of the skeletal products.  This experiment-based research also provided training, education and financial support to graduate and undergraduate students as they conducted these studies in partial fulfillment of their science degrees. 

 

The findings became possible after we developed a new type of flow through reactor that can reproducibly synthesize ACC (amorphous calcium carbonate, CaCO3) materials to desired compositions.  Previous efforts had used batch methods that could not know or control chemical conditions over the course of synthesis.  By the flow-through approach, we gained the ability to tune the Mg content of ACC by tuning the initial solution Mg/Ca, total inorganic carbon concentration, and pH.   Much was learned about ACC properties using this approach.  For the subsequent transformation studies, the ACC products were allowed to transform within the output suspension under stirred or quiescent conditions while characterizing the evolving solutions and solids. 

 

There were many outcomes and the study met/exceeded original objectives.  The detailed findings and original data and appendices of supplementary information are published in peer-reviewed journals.  They are also presented in student theses, dissertations, and undergraduate reports. 

 

Findings from the ACC composition and transformation studies: 1) Established the interplay of factors that control Mg content of amorphous calcium carbonate;  2) Determined quantitative framework to predict initial polymorph that forms from ACC based upon solution aMg2+/aCa2+ and aCO32-/aCa2+ and stirring versus quiescent conditions; 3) Explained apparent discrepancies between previous studies that report on the nature of the polymorphs produced from ACC and supports the previous claim that monohydrocalcite may be an important, but overlooked, transient phase prior to aragonite and calcite.  4) Demonstrated that organic additives and extreme pH are not required to tune the composition and nature of the polymorph that forms.  5) Mineralization via ACC can lead to crystalline phases whose polymorphs and compositions are out of equilibrium with the local media.  Classical thermodynamics may not provide a reliable predictor of observed compositions because kinetic factors often have a significant influence.  

 

Findings from the isotope tracer study of the ACC to crystalline transformation process:  1) Tested four pathways for the transformation using Magnesium and calcium stable isotope labeling.  2) Demonstrated the ACC to crystalline polymorph transformation is best explained by a dissolution-reprecipitation process.  3) Conducted comparisons of the measurements to the predictions of a simple mixing model.  Found that calcite compositions are i) sensitive to relative amounts of ACC and the surrounding solution reservoir and ii) primarily governed by conditions at the time of transformation rather than the initial ACC composition.  4) Shifts in calcite composition over the duration of the transformation period reflect the progressive evolution of the local solution conditions.  This dependence suggests the extent to which there is water available would change the end point composition on the mixing line.  These findings have significant geochemical implications, but the question remains whether this transformation pathway is followed when biomineralization involves ACC or is particular to these inorganic experiments. 

 

Many broader impacts emerged from this work for marine biomineralization and their significance grew to additional fields of science and engineering over the project period. 

 

For example, the project complemented a separate effort by PI Dove and other scientists from the geosciences, materials, chemistry and physics international communities.  Their goal was to understand evidence from high-resolution studies that show many crystals grow by the formation and aggregation of different types of particles.  From this effort, we learned that the diverse set of pathways is governed by different types of kinetic factors that map over the traditional thermodynamic picture of crystal growth (De Yoreo et al., 2015, Science).   The ACC to carbonate mineral transformation focus of this NSF study is one of those pathways amongst many. 

 

A predictive understanding of crystallization by particle attachment (CPA), which is now recognized to dominate also solution-based growth of important semiconductor, oxide, and metallic nanomaterials, promises advances in nanomaterials design and synthesis for diverse applications.  With a mechanism-based understanding, CPA processes can be exploited to produce hierarchical structures that retain the size-dependent attributes of their nanoscale building blocks and create materials with enhanced or novel physical and chemical properties.

 

The findings from this project, in combination with the emerging understanding of crystal growth by particle interactions, reiterate the need to revisit the traditional picture of chemical and physical controls on biomineral growth.  By approaching crystal growth through the lens of multiple particle-based pathways to crystallization, an improved process-based approach to mineral formation, including composition and properties, becomes possible for everything from marine animal skeletons to sediment formation and new materials synthesis for advanced technological applications.
